p: The main global threats to coral species are related with greenhouse gas emissions (RCP), especially CO 2 [ 118]. Effects of such impacts have lead to decline of biodiversity in reefs of Brazil and of the world, through increase of sea temperature and ocean acidification [ 11]. Local impacts boost these effects through higher sedimentation, multiple biological invasions, bleaching, coral diseases and, consequently, loose of diversity on reef environments [ 11, 141, 142, 143]. Such impacts are frequently related to disorganized urban growth, pollution, messy tourism practices and overfishing [ 144, 145, 146]. In the literature M. harttii used to be described as forming extensive bands on coastal reefs, showing colonies usually up to 1 m in diameter [ 120]. Currently, this is a rare scenario for most of these reefs, which often have a low coral coverage, not corresponding the descriptions of the 1970â€™s.
